prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the author is in the wrong for telling their friend that having five kids by different fathers is why she's single. 

First, the friend has been making hurtful comments about the author for two years. The author kept brushing them off, but finally snapped and gave a direct answer. The mutual friends now side with the friend, accusing the author of having privilege and being a bad friend.

So, the key points here: the author was responding to years of insults. The friend's comments were personal and targeted the author's weight, job, and dating life. The author's response was a blunt truth about the friend's situation. But the friends are now taking the author's side of the story and judging them. 

Is it wrong to tell the truth? Well, even if the truth is true, the way it's delivered matters. The author was defensive after being insulted, so their response was a direct cause-and-effect statement. But could there have been a better way to phrase it without attacking the friend? Maybe. However, the friend's behavior was abusive over time, and the author was defending themselves. 

The author's job and their financial situation are mentioned, which shows they have their own struggles. The friends are quick to judge the author as privileged without understanding their background. The friend's actions (multiple divorces, child support issues) are her own problems, so the author pointing out the obvious might not be wrong. 

But in terms of friendship, honesty is important, but the method and timing matter. The author might have acted in self-defense after years of being insulted. The friends' reactions seem biased, maybe because they weren't aware of the prior context. 

So, considering all that, the author isn't in the wrong. They were responding to years of abuse and gave a truthful, albeit blunt, response. The friends' judgment isn't justified without knowing the full story. So answer B.
